Expectation1: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation1: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: The morning sun filtered through the stained glass as I prepared the altar for the most significant religious holiday of the year. The church was already filling with anticipation; this was the day my congregation needed me most, to lead them in prayer and celebration. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder of the routine legal meeting scheduled at the courthouse, a meeting I was expected to attend as an advocate. The law firm had been clear: punctuality and presence were non-negotiable, even for routine matters. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My parishioners looked to me for spiritual guidance, especially today, while my clients and colleagues depended on my legal expertise and reliability. My heart pounded as I glanced at the clock, torn between the sacred duty before me and the professional obligation awaiting me across town. The expectations of both roles clashed within me, each demanding my full presence, each unwilling to yield. I stood at the threshold, caught between the call to serve my faith and the call to uphold justice, uncertain which path to take.
